history.content: It depends. How familiar are you with continuous distributions? The topics that you should know well for 135 and other 15x stat upper div's are joint distributions (uniform, non-uniform), standard normal distributions, continuous conditional probability/distributions, conditional expectations (continuous and discrete), bivariate normal distribution, CDFs/PDFs. If you are comfortable enough with these distributions (not just knowing them, see if you can do the problems from Pitman's Probability book to test yourself), then I'd say you'd be in a good spot for 135/15x.

children.subject:
Honestly, R is not that hard to self-teach. It's extremely simple (~50% of the difficulty of 61A imo), and the only thing that may trip you up is the syntax. I think you can go through the entire 133 syllabus in about a week if you any kind of programming experience past 61A, so I don't think 133 is really all that essential (if you know your stuff). 

Will 135 provide a good foundation for 189/ML? Of course. I've read somewhere on the Piazza that Prof. El Ghaoui recommends 135, 153, and 155 out of the stat department for ML-related stuff.
But should I take it over 123? I'm not sure if I should wait 123 till my last semester and possibly forget 120 materials by then.

I think I'm ready for 135, but I'm not sure if I can jump straight to 153 if I choose to take 123 instead of 135 next semester. 

I'm pretty familiar with the list you've provided and probably will be solving bunch of problems in 126. 

I just want to know if 135 & R will be necessary before 153 and if 135 will give a nice statistical foundation for ml and be prioritized over 123.

history.content:
Hi I'm a 3rd year EECS who took CS 189 & EE 120 this semester.

I was thinking of taking Stat 135 and EE 123 next semester along with EECS 126 & 127, but the 2 classes have the same lecture time so I probably have to choose one.  I'm leaning towards 123 which I think is offered only spring, but I'm not sure if I want to wait till my senior year to take 135. Any thoughts on what to take?

Also, does anyone know if 153 is doable without 134/135 and knowing R? I was considering 135 for more statistical background for ml and to prep for 153 next Fall (which would be after taking 126).
history.subject: Stat 135 vs EE 123
